member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.RandomAccessFilterStrategyBase
member.summary: Base class for filter strategies which implement for performance optimisation

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.IFilterStrategy
member.summary: A filter strategy is a pluggable component that can be used in conjunction with a to provide a view on the data contained in an instance.
member.remarks: Note that when implementing this interface it is the responsibility of the implementation to ensure that the indexes contained in the INotifyCollectionChangedArgs when the CollectionChanged event is raised match up with the data returned from the GetEnumerator call such that the index 0 refers to the first element returned and index n refers to the (n+1)th element returned. Failure to correctly maintain this relationship this may cause unexpected behaviour during the addition or modification of data points at runtime.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.INotifyPropertyChangedRelayer
member.summary: Relays PropertyChanged events from a number of sources.

remarks.para: The INotifyPropertyChangedRelayer interface is typically used to wrap a collection of INotifyPropertyChanged objects, collect their PropertyChanged events and fire a relayed PropertyChangedRelay event.

The interface is useful because the client subscribing to the PropertyChangedRelay event of this interface does not have to deal with individually subscribing/unsubscribing to the PropertyChanged events of the sources because the implementation should have taken care of this.
The class extends , and can be used in place of where PropertyChanged event relaying is desired.

member.name: E:Visiblox.Charts.INotifyPropertyChangedRelayer.PropertyChangedRelay
member.summary: Occurs when a property value has changed on any of the members.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.IFilterStrategy.GetSearchableSeries
member.summary: Get the searchable data series associated with this DataSeries. This can either be the series itself, or some internal series that handles the sorting and searching.
member.returns: An implementation of the ISearchable interface that can be used for efficient searching of DataPoints or null if unsupported.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.IFilterStrategy.Init(Visiblox.Charts.IAxis,Visiblox.Charts.IAxis,Visiblox.Charts.IDataSeries)
member.summary: Initialises the strategy. This will be called by the FilteredDataSeries when the chart is sufficiently initialised. The FilteredDataSeries will continue to call Init until returns true.
member.remarks: If for any reason the FilterStrategy requires to be reinitialised, simply returning false from will have that effect.

If the implementer keeps references to any of the parameters passed to the Init method, it is the responsibility of the implementation to update those references. When the underlying axes are changed, Axis ValueConversion events will be raised for the appropriate axis. Similarly if the OriginalDataSeries is replaced, a reset event will be generated and passed to the OnOriginalCollectionChanged method with the new OriginalDataSeries as the sender.
member.param: The x-axis against which the data is being plotted.
The y-axis against which the data is being plotted.
The original unfiltered data. It is not advisable to keep a reference to this beyond the scope of this method.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.AxisBase`1
member.summary: Provides a base implementation of . An represents a single chart axis which may be vertical or horizontal.

remarks.para: See for a discussion of the general responsibilities of an axis.

provides a base axis implementation which handles the logic required to render an axis. In particular AxisBase handles rendering of the axis line, title, ticks and grid stripes, and labels. AxisBase also takes care of coordinate conversion between data values and render positions, and the relationship between and 's EffectiveMaximum and EffectiveMinum members.

To provide a new axis implementation, a subclass must implement and to specify what spacing ticks, labels, grid lines and grid stripes are given. Other virtual methods are provided for further customisation.
If an invalid is supplied, the will remain the same. A null will cause the to be auto-calculated.
If the defines either a TextAlignment or HorizontalAlignment, but not both, these two will be equivalent to each other.
If a is explicitly set, will have no effect and labels will be displayed at the given angle.

member.typeparam: The value type for this axis.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.AxisCommonBase`1
member.summary: Provides a base implementation of .
member.remarks: Implements responsibilities that all Visiblox Charts axes need to have. This includes declaring shared properties that defines (mostly related to styling, formatting and tick intervals), implementing basic handling of the and implementing style properties and other properties shared among the axes.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.IAxisCommon
member.summary: Represents an interface that defines axes for both Cartesian and radial charts.

remarks.para: All Visiblox Charts axes have an (either horizontal or vertical) and a .

The axes also define two ranges. The is the range set by the user, is the range that's auto-calculated by the axis, taking into account if set. Different types of axes use different implementations of . In order to maintain encapsulation each axis provides a factory method, , used to construct a new instance of the appropriate implementation of .

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.IRangeProvider
member.summary: An interface holding all the relevant information for axes with .

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.IRangeProvider.SetActualRange(Visiblox.Charts.IRange)
member.summary: If the axis does not have an explicit range set, the chart will automatically calculate a suitable range, with margins, for this axis, setting it via this method. This method should only be called by the chart or an axis implementation.
member.param: Range to scale the axis to.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.IRangeProvider.CreateRange
member.summary: Factory method. Returns the range type used by the axis implementation.
member.example: An axis that uses a double scale would return a . One using categories would return a .
member.returns: The IRange implementation used by the concrete axis.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.IRangeProvider.GrowActualRange
member.summary: In the event that the EffectiveMinimum == EffectiveMaximum, we may need to grow the range by MajorTickInterval at either side; this lets concrete Axis classes do that

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.IRangeProvider.Range
member.summary: Gets or sets the user-specified range for this axis.

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.IRangeProvider.ActualRange
member.summary: Gets the actual derived range of this axis, without zoom applied. This object is volatile as it may be recomputed as a result of changes in data, range or zoom.
member.remarks: This range is either the user-specified if set, or otherwise calculated based on the data.

remarks.b: Do not change the properties on this object as it may be overwritten by the chart. Instead use to set a specific range.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.IAxis
member.summary: Represents a single Cartesian chart axis which may be vertical or horizontal.

remarks.para: An is situated along one edge of the chart's plot area (depending on the orientation and specified location of the axis). Visually, it is responsible for the calculation and display of ticks and labels, and for adding grid lines on the chart's plot area.
The is also responsible for the calculations converting between data values and plot area coordinates, and handling the range of data displayed along this axis.

The axis supports zooming through the property. When this property is changed the axis redraws itself. Also, components of the (such as series and behaviours) render themselves based on the zoom value of the chart's axes.

The axis has multiple range properties:
- The client supplied range. This may be null.
- The actual axis range. If Range is specified in most cases the ActualRange will equal the Range exactly, otherwise ActualRange is computed automatically.

The axis contains 2 distinct coordinate systems:
The Data Value- this coordinate system is defined in the data value space. This can contain any of the supported Data types, e.g. double, DateTime, etc.
The Render Position - this coordinate system is defined within the chart's PlotArea. It is used to return a coordinate where the shape can be drawn. As such, it is scaled from the top in the Y direction, not the bottom.

The will automatically create axes based upon the supplied data, but chart users will often wish to specify their own axes in order to use a different axis type, or customise the various properties of an axis.
To implement a new axis, it is recommended to inherit from .

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.IAxis.GetDataValueAsRenderPositionWithZoom(System.IComparable)
member.summary: Determines the render position within chart's plot area where the data value would be plotted WITH the zoom applied.
member.example: On an axis with Horizontal ; a rendered at the far left of the axis (with zoom) would return 0, rendered at the far right would return the Axis' ActualWidth.
On an axis with Vertical ; a rendered at the top of the axis (with zoom) would return 0, rendered at the bottom would return the Axis' ActualHeight.
Should the currently be displayed off the side of the axis, a negative or greater than the width/height position may be returned.
member.param: The data value for which to get the render position.
member.returns: Render position where should be plotted or Double.NaN if the provided data value is not able to be plotted.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.IAxis.GetDataValueAsRenderPositionWithoutZoom(System.IComparable)
member.summary: Determines the render position within chart's plot area where the data value would be plotted WITHOUT the zoom applied. I.e. this method returns a value which would be the same as invoking without the axis being zoomed in.
member.remarks: This method returns where the would be rendered without zoom applied, regardless of whether a zoom has actually been applied or not.
member.example: On an axis with Horizontal ; a rendered at the far left of the axis would return 0, rendered at the far right would return the Axis' ActualWidth.
On an axis with Vertical ; a rendered at the top of the axis would return 0, rendered at the bottom would return the Axis' ActualHeight.
Should the currently be displayed off the side of the axis, a negative or greater than the width/height position may be returned.
member.param: The data value for which to get the render position.
member.returns: Render position where would be plotted or Double.NaN if the provided data value is not able to be plotted.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.IAxis.GetRenderPositionAsDataValueWithZoom(System.Double)
member.summary: Converts a render space coordinate position (relative to the chart's plot area) into a data space value, taking the zoom into account.
member.example: If this axis is a AxisBase<DateTime> then it will convert the double position to the value that it represents on the axis with zoom applied.
member.param: The render position relative to the plot area in screen coordinates.
member.returns: The data value that the specified render position maps to considering the current zoom level.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.IAxis.GetRenderPositionAsDataValueWithoutZoom(System.Double)
member.summary: Converts a render space coordinate position (relative to the chart's plot area) into a data space value, without taking the zoom into account.
member.example: If this axis is a AxisBase<DateTime> then it will convert the double position to the value that it represents on the axis.
member.param: The render position relative to the plot area in screen coordinates.
member.returns: The data value that the specified render position would map to if the chart were not zoomed.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.IAxis.Init(System.Windows.Controls.Grid,Visiblox.Charts.AxisLocation,System.Windows.Controls.Orientation)
member.summary: Invoked by the when an axis is initially added to the chart or its location within the chart is changed.
member.remarks: This method allows the axis to obtain a reference to the Grid UI element that is the chart's layout root, as well as the of the axis in relation to the plot area (e.g. primary (left or bottom) or secondary (right or top)), and the of the axis (i.e. vertical or horizontal). Typically initialisation would include adding grid lines (which are the responsibility of each axis).
member.param: The root Grid of the chart's control template.
The location of the axis within the chart, this can be used to determine how to render the axis.
The orientation of the axis (i.e. vertical or horizontal).

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.IAxis.DeInit
member.summary: Invoked by the chart when an axis is removed from display. Typically used to remove grid lines and anything else set up in the method.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.IAxis.GetZoom(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Determines the zoom required such that the indicated render position (i.e. pixel) range fills the axis.
member.remarks: Determines the Zoom value that would be required in order to zoom the axis such that the range described by the startPoint and endPoint pixel coordinates fills the axis. For example, if this is a horizontal axis with an ActualWidth of 500 pixels, invoking GetZoom with start and end points of 100 and 200 respectively would provide a zoom, which when applied to the axis, would result in the data within this 100 pixel range filling the entire axis.
member.param: The start point, in render coordinates.
The end point, in render coordinates.
member.returns: The computed zoom, or null if no zoom could be computed.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.IAxis.AdoptZoomAsRange
member.summary: Normalises the of the axis to represent the effective range of the axis with a default (i.e. scale 1 and offset 0).

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.IAxis.Zoom
member.summary: Gets or sets the zoom applied to this axis. This property is used by components of the to determine their position and size when plotting themselves.

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.IAxis.ActualRange
member.summary: Gets the actual derived range of this axis, without zoom applied. This object is volatile as it may be recomputed as a result of changes in data, range or zoom.

remarks.para: This range is either the user-specified if set, or otherwise calculated based on the data.

para.b: Do not change the properties on this object as it may be overwritten by the chart. Instead use IAxis.Range to set a specific range.

remarks.para: To obtain the range with zoom applied, see the and properties of this range object.

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.IAxis.ActualRenderedRange
member.summary: Get the actual rendered range of the axis taking the window scaling factor into account.
member.remarks: This value may be computed asynchronously as the axis is not rendered immediately. In most cases the should be used to obtain the and which define the

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.IAxis.ReverseAxis
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the axis is reversed. A reversed axis will render in the reverse order, such that the smaller values are at the right or top and the larger values are at the left or bottom of an X or Y axis respectively.

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.IAxis.SupportsStreaming
member.summary: Indicates whether the axis supports streaming optimizations. It will only take effect if the chart is not set to None.
member.remarks: Only set it to true if the axis plots continuous values.

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.IAxis.AutoScaleToVisibleData
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the axis range should be computed to include only data currently visible on the chart on the basis of another axis' range.
member.remarks: If enabled, the axis will be rendered each time the visible data changes. This is particularly useful when setting the range of one axis manually resulting in data points no longer on the chart's visible area.

Note that the use of this property is only required when wanting to restrict the auto-calculated range of one axis based on the data currently included by the range on another. Take the example where the data series contains the first 10 integer points of the function y=x from 0 to 9, but the x-axis range was restricted manually to the range 0-3. If is set to false on the y-axis its range will be calculated as 0-9, taking into consideration all points in the data series. If is set to true on the y-axis its range will be calculated as 0-3, taking into consideration only those points shown based on the x-axis' range.

This property is not required to make the axis automatically calculate a range based on the data contained in the data series, that will automatically happen by default unless an explicit is set by the user.

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.IAxis.IsAutoMarginEnabled
member.summary: Gets or sets whether margins are enabled for auto-generated ranges on this axis.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.AxisBase`1.GetDataValueAsAxisValue(`0)
member.summary: Converts a data value into an arbitrary double scale. This removes the complexity of converting to/from a render position which is handled in .
member.remarks: Converting a Data value to and from a Render position requires finding the data value relative to the current location of the left most Data value and the height/width of the chart. This method is provided to remove the need to implement this boiler plate code and allow an implementation to simply convert the Data value into an arbitrary double scale, which will be converted to a render position internally.
This is the inverse of .
member.example: A DateTime axis implementation could use the Ticks value of the DateTime passed through.
A double-based axis implementation could simply return the Data value as a double.
member.param: A data value.
member.returns: Arbitrary axis value corresponding to .

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.AxisBase`1.GetAxisValueAsDataValue(System.Double)
member.summary: Converts a value in the arbitrary double scale into a data value. This removes the complexity of converting to/from a render position which is handled in .
member.remarks: Converting a Data value to and from a Render position requires finding the data value relative to the current location of the left most Data value and the height/width of the chart. This method is provided to remove the need to implement this boiler plate code and allow an implementation to simply convert an arbitrary double scale into the Data value, which will be converted to a render position internally.
This is the inverse of .
member.example: A DateTime axis implementation could return the DateTime value of the number of Ticks passed through.
A double-based axis implementation could simply return the double as the Data value.
member.param: The value (in the axis specific axis range) to retrieve as a data value.
member.returns: Data value corresponding to .

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.AxisBase`1.LayoutCycleDetectionLimit
member.summary: Gets or sets the time window used to constrain layout cycle detection (in ms). Layout cycles can occur when different chart elements (such as the axes) cause each other to resize in a loop, and will cause the application to hang/crash. The chart tries to avoid this by detecting repeated cyclical size changes which occur during the specified time window. A large value may cause false positives, leading to incorrect rendering, whereas a small value may not detect a layout cycle. A non-positive value will disable this detection. This is a Dependency Property.

member.typeparam: The IComparable data type being used by the Axis.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.AxisZoomCanvasBase
member.summary: Canvas for rendering ticks and labels on the axis. Responsible for detecting collisions and plotting elements to avoid collision when this is required. Rendering is based on the , , and properties.

remarks.para: Custom logic is applied to render elements correctly on horizontal and vertical axes (based on the property), primary and secondary axes (based on the property), and depending if labels are to be displayed inside or outside of the axis (based on the property).

If collision is detected, elements are first displayed alternating, then rotated 90 degrees to avoid collision. If rotated elements are still colliding, labels are dropped until such time that there are no collisions.

Collision detection is only done for elements that have the CheckForCollision attached property set to true. Typically this property is set true for labels and false for ticks by the axis that contains this canvas.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.Primitives.ZoomCanvas
member.summary: Represents a canvas which provides a zooming effect for its child elements.
member.remarks: A ZoomCanvas behaves like a which can reposition / scale its child elements based on its and properties. Like , ZoomCanvas has a property which is a collection containing the items displayed on the canvas. In addition, ZoomCanvas defines two attached dependency properties which control the repositioning or rescaling of these items. The ZoomCanvas.ElementPosition property defines the position of a , which will be changed on zoom to move the element appropriately (without rescaling it). Alternatively, the ZoomCanvas.IsScaledPath property indicates that a should be rescaled on zoom, so that it will be enlarged or shrunk appropriately. ZoomCanvas.ElementPosition should be used to handle shapes on which a resizing effect is not desired when zooming in (e.g. points on a line series, where the size of the ellipses should remain constant regardless of the zoom factor). ZoomCanvas.IsScaledPath should be set where a path defining the child of the zoom canvas should have the zoom applied to it (e.g. columns in a column chart, which should become larger when zooming in). Note also when making changes to an element for which IsScaledPath is set to true, a manual call to should be made to notify the chart to update the scaling of that element.
member.example: The following example creates a ZoomCanvas in XAML, with a square set to be scaled, and a circle set to be repositioned. The XZoom is set to 0.5, resulting in half as much data being shown and an apparent 'zoom in'. No offset is applied, so the shapes' bottom left corner will remain in the same location. As the square has ZoomCanvas.IsScaledPath set to true, the square will becomes a rectangle twice as wide as it is high.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.IAxisElementContainer
member.summary: An Axis will use an implementation of an IAxisElementContainer to render its ticks and labels along with any other UI Elements it wishes to show.
member.remarks:
The responsibilities of an IAxisElementContainer include: - Rendering the elements of an Axis (such a ticks marks, labels and additional labels). - Refreshing those elements when necessary - This may include altering the position in line with changes to the Axis (for Zoom, Pan, etc) and updating any text or values they display - Measuring both its elements and itself.
For this, the container will/may need the following information from the Axis:
The tick values and their respective render positions
Tick styles and size (for both Major and Minor ticks)
Label styles, angle and position (inside/outside)
Any label collision detection that should be performed
Whether overflowing labels are allowed
Orientation and Location of Axis

member.param: Flag indicating if any labels should be widened if alignment is Stretch.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.CategoryAxis
member.summary: Represents an axis where the values are discrete categories.

remarks.para: CategoryAxis will show a major tick for each distinct category plotted against it, and no minor ticks. This is often used in bar and column charts, and more generally wherever the axis labels are discrete values which should not be subdivided in any way.
The determines the set of categories, and their ordering, if this is not specified the categories will be taken from the data values in their series order.
By default margins are displayed on the axis, these can be turned off by setting to false. It is recommended to do so e.g. when using on the chart.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.DateTimeAxis
member.summary: Represents an axis where the values are of type.

remarks.para: This is the default axis type which the chart will automatically create if the data consists of values, but will often be explicitly created by the chart user in order to set the various axis properties.

By default this axis formats labels according to the , which if not specified is calculated from the axis range. This means that when the chart is showing years of data, the labels will show the year, but if the visible data is in a range of around a day, hours will be shown on the labels. In addition, when the data range is small labels are periodically replaced by labels at a higher scale, so that for example when only hours are visible the midnight label may also display the date at that point. This behaviour can be customised by replacing the , or a single format for all scales can be set using the (which takes precedence over the if set).

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.ILogicalAxis
member.summary:
Represents a single logical axis which has no visual display.
The axis has multiple range properties:
- The client supplied range. This may be null.
- The actual axis range. If Range is specified in most cases the ActualRange will equal the Range exactly, otherwise ActualRange is computed automatically.

member.summary: Converts the given which is a value represented in the data space into the equivalent value represented in the logical space
member.param: The data value for which to return the logical one.
member.returns: The logical value corresponding to the given .

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.ILogicalAxis.GetLogicalValueAsDataValue(System.Object)
member.summary: Converts the given which is a value represented in the logical space into the equivalent value represented in the data space
member.param: The logical value for which to return the data value.
member.returns: The data value which corresponds to the given .

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.ILogicalAxis.Zoom
member.summary: Gets or sets the zoom applied to this axis. This property is used by components of the to determine their position and size when plotting themselves.

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.ILogicalAxis.ActualRange
member.summary: Gets the actual derived range of this axis, without zoom applied. This object is volatile as it may be recomputed as a result of changes in data, range or zoom.
member.remarks: This range is either the user-specified if set, or otherwise calculated based on the data.

remarks.b: Do not change the properties on this object as it may be overwritten by the chart. Instead use IAxis.Range to set a specific range.

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.ILogicalAxis.ScalingDimension
member.summary: Get or set the dimension used to determine the number of readable logical values

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.ILogicalAxis.AutoScaleToVisibleData
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the axis range should be computed to include only data currently visible on the chart on the basis of another axis' range.
member.remarks: If enabled, the axis will be rendered each time the visible data changes. This is particularly useful when setting the range of one axis manually resulting in data points no longer on the chart's visible area.

Note that the use of this property is only required when wanting to restrict the auto-calculated range of one axis based on the data currently included by the range on another. Take the example where the data series contains the first 10 integer points of the function y=x from 0 to 9, but the x-axis range was restricted manually to the range 0-3. If is set to false on the y-axis its range will be calculated as 0-9, taking into consideration all points in the data series. If is set to true on the y-axis its range will be calculated as 0-3, taking into consideration only those points shown based on the x-axis' range.

This property is not required to make the axis automatically calculate a range based on the data contained in the data series, that will automatically happen by default unless an explicit is set by the user.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.AxisLabelCollisionDetectionMode
member.summary: A list of possible collision detection schemes that an Axis can use when checking for label collisions.

member.name: F:Visiblox.Charts.AxisLabelCollisionDetectionMode.None
member.summary: No collision detection will take place; all labels will be rendered in a single line.

member.name: F:Visiblox.Charts.AxisLabelCollisionDetectionMode.Hide
member.summary: Hide colliding labels. This will determine the optimum number of labels that should be hidden in order to make the remaining labels clearly visible.

member.name: F:Visiblox.Charts.AxisLabelCollisionDetectionMode.Offset
member.summary: When labels collide, a second row is created below the first and every other label is placed on this row. If collisions still take place after offsetting, no more action is taken.

member.name: F:Visiblox.Charts.AxisLabelCollisionDetectionMode.Rotate
member.summary: Labels are rotated through 90 degrees to avoid collision. If there are still collisions after rotation, no more action is taken.

member.name: F:Visiblox.Charts.AxisLabelCollisionDetectionMode.OffsetOrRotate
member.summary: First tries to use the Offset scheme to avoid collision and if that fails, attempts the Rotate scheme.

member.name: F:Visiblox.Charts.AxisLabelCollisionDetectionMode.RotateAndHide
member.summary: Hides any colliding labels after rotating through 90 degrees. This will determine the optimum number of labels that should be hidden in order to make the remaining labels clearly visible.

member.name: F:Visiblox.Charts.AxisLabelCollisionDetectionMode.Auto
member.summary: Tries to use scheme OffsetOrRotate followed by Hide followed by RotateAndHide to avoid collisions.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.DefaultRenderManager
member.summary: A default implementation of the IRenderManager, used by the AxisZoomCanvas. This implementation has some logic for detecting collisions and altering the label layout based on those collisions. It is also responsible for offsetting the label position based on the angle they are set to.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.IRenderManager
member.summary: An interface that can be used to apply specific logic to how an Axis renders its tick and tick label elements.
member.remarks: The default AxisZoomCanvas expects all render coordinates to be given with respect to the ZoomCanvas that the ticks and labels are being rendered onto. Any offsets applied to ticks and labels should be given relative to the initial render position of the FrameworkElement.

The position of the tick mark.
member.returns: A Point object with the correct coordinates for the tick.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.BehaviourEventThrottler`1
member.summary: Generic event throttling based on the approach in http://www.scottlogic.co.uk/blog/colin/2010/06/throttling-silverlight-mouse-events-to-keep-the-ui-responsive/
member.remarks: A payload of type is supplied to every time an interaction event occurs; a throttled version of this is raised as .
member.typeparam: Type of event payload data

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.BehaviourEventThrottler`1.#ctor
member.summary: Construct new event throttler

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.BehaviourEventThrottler`1.ReceiveAction(`0)
member.summary: Performs an action with the given , conditional on whether the chart has rendered since the last pan.
member.remarks: This method is initially called due to a mouse move event. If the CompositionTarget.Rendering event has not yet fired since last update, this method will be called again via a timer in case the mouse stops moving and the position still needs updated. When the mouse button is released, this will be called in a couple of stages in order to ensure the queued events are rendered before raising the compelted event.
member.param: Event payload data

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.BehaviourEventThrottler`1.UpdatePendingActionData(`0)
member.summary: Update the pending action data without triggering an interaction
member.param: Interaction data

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.BehaviourManager
member.summary: A container for a number of instances, allowing multiple behaviours to be added to a chart.

remarks.para: Depending on the setting of , the BehaviourManager either allows one behaviour to be enabled on the chart at once, or any number.

Behaviours are added to the collection, and individual behaviours may be enabled (or disabled) via the property. The BehaviourManager passes chart interaction events through to each enabled behaviour.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.CrosshairBehaviour
member.summary: A behaviour that displays a crosshair on the chart plot area.

remarks.para: CrosshairBehaviour displays a crosshair on the chart plot area, giving a readout of the data values under the mouse position. The crosshair consists of vertical and horizontal lines running across the chart through the cursor position, and a label positioned by the cursor indicating the X and Y axis data values under the crosshair.
The crosshair can be styled by setting .
X and Y labels can be turned on or off by setting the property. They can be set to hide underlying axis labels by setting to true.
Labels on both the X and Y axis can be formatted using the , , , , , properties for the X axis and respectively the , , , , , properties for the Y axis.

member.example: The following XAML defines an example crosshair template and style, resulting in a red crosshair with thicker dashed lines:

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.PanBehaviour
member.summary: A behaviour that pans the chart when it is dragged, or when cursor keys are pressed.

remarks.para: Panning is accomplished by updating the of a while the chart is being dragged. This also takes into account the to ensure the panning is correct while zoomed in.
It is possible to pan in both directions or to disable panning on X and/or Y through and .
Two cursors can also be set to offer a visual indication: when panning is available and when panning is in progress.
Note that the offsets are applied to all axes on the chart so that the axes remain in sync with one another.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.PanBehaviour.#ctor
member.summary: Constructor.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.PanBehaviour.AllowPan(Visiblox.Charts.IAxis,System.Double)
member.summary: Determine whether to allow the pan which has just taken place to proceed.
member.param: The axis being panned

When called the axis' offset will reflect the "new" offset as if this method returns true to ease effective range calculations. This parameter reflects the previous offset so that drag direction can be determined where necessary.
member.returns: True if the pan is to be permitted and false otherwise.

member.summary: Returns the axes that should be panned, based on what the most recent was and the value of .

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.RulerBehaviour
member.summary: A behaviour that allows the user to measure parts of a plot area by dragging a 'ruler'

remarks.para: The ruler is placed using single clicks. This allows the zoom and ruler behaviour to be used in conjunction. The first click begins drawing the ruler. After that, the ruler will follow the mouse. The second click 'locks' the ruler in its current position and a third clears the ruler. Once the ruler has been locked, the sides can still be dragged into new positions if is set to true.

Snapping may be enabled by setting to true. If you are measuring the xaxis, it will snap to points on the xaxis and similarly, if you are measuring the y axis, it will snap to points on the y axis. When measuring both axes, it will snap to the x axis, however enabling allows you to drag and snap to the y axis.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.TrackballBehaviour
member.summary: A behaviour that displays a at the closest data-point(s) to the mouse pointer.

remarks.para: TrackballBehaviour displays a on each series indicating the data point which is closest (considering the in operation) to the mouse pointer. By default a trackball is added to every series on the chart, however if series are added to the behaviour's collection, only those series will display trackballs.

The point(s) indicated by the trackball are exposed via the collection. In common usage, the current point of the trackball will be bound to some visual indication on the screen (see the example below).

The visual appearance of a particular trackball is specified by the associated series. Any series extending specifies a and . The series will specify a suitable default appearance for the trackball, but by setting these properties it is possible to customise the trackball of a particular series (examples are given under ).

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.ZoomBehaviour
member.summary: A behaviour that allows the user to zoom the chart by dragging a rectangular region across the plot area.

remarks.para: By default the zoom is animated. This can be turned off by setting to false. The animation duration can be controlled by setting the property.
The style of the rectangle drawn to indicate the zoom area can be changed by setting the property. The zoom rectangle can be modified more extensively via the property.

Note that the zoom is applied to all axes on the chart so that the axes remain in sync with one another. Axes can be excluded from zooming if they are added to the or if zooming in a given direction is disabled with or .

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.Chart
member.summary: Represents a Cartesian chart. A chart has 2 or more axes, and may contain a number of different kinds of series, a title and a legend. Charts are richly interactive and able to be styled.

remarks.para: Chart takes care of generating all of its components needed for display, the developer only has to add one or more to its collection to plot data.

Chart is designed to be fully customizable. The most important customization possibilities are the following:
Axes - The Chart must always have one or and either one or . If not supplied an axis will be automatically created based on the type of data supplied to the provided chart series. Additionally, a chart may have one or more additional x or y axes on either side of the chart by adding instances to , , and . Each axis has a range which handles the range of data values to be displayed. If not supplied, the chart will auto-calculate the range based on the data. When streaming live data, you can improve the performance by setting the to the appropriate value in order to pan the axis and accommodate the added data instead of recalculating the range.
Styling - Both the Chart container and its components can be fully styled using styling related properties. Chart allows the styling of the series in various ways. Styling related properties can be set on the individual series, the property can be set on the series, or the property can be used to define a palette and apply it to the chart. Specifying style related properties on the individual series has the highest precedence, this followed by specifying the NormalStyle, finally by declaring a custom Palette. If none of these are specified, the default Chart Palette will be applied to the series.
Interaction - Interaction is supported through behaviours. A behaviour () needs to be assigned to the property of the chart to enable various interactions. Examples for behaviours include and . Note that by assigning a to Behaviour, multiple behaviours can be assigned to the chart.

Chart implements to provide offsets to which can be rendered in a side-by-side context - where the width of the rendered data points is dependent upon other data points from other series at that particular render position.

example.para:
Create a simple chart with a single line series:
Example output:

Customizing the Chart can be done through either the style related properties or by changing its layout via setting the property and changing its control template. By default the following template is applied to the chart. Use this as a base for changing the chart's control template.

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.ChartBase.LayoutCycleDetectionLimit
member.summary: Gets or sets the time window used to constrain layout cycle detection (in ms). Layout cycles can occur when different chart elements (such as the axes) cause each other to resize in a loop, and will cause the application to hang/crash. The chart tries to avoid this by detecting repeated cyclical size changes which occur during the specified time window. A large value may cause false positives, leading to incorrect rendering, whereas a small value may not detect a layout cycle. A non-positive value will disable this detection. This is a Dependency Property.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.IOffsetProvider
member.summary: An IOffsetProvider is responsible for calculating offsets to be applied to the rendering position or geometry of an .

remarks.para: IOffsetProvider provides offset values to a querying in order to adjust the render position or geometry. As such, methods declared by IOffsetProvider are called during the Invalidation process of an IChartSeries.

implements IOffsetProvider to represent the concept that it is responsible for providing offsets to all of the which are held within its Series property. IOffsetProvider exposes the ability for offsets to be applied to IChartSeries rendered as in a side-by-side context, such as . Not all IChartSeries operate within a side-by-side context, and therefore not all series will interface with Chart as its IOffsetProvider.
The subclass provides extra methods which can be called in order to perform stacking on series.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.IOffsetProvider.GetBaseAxisOffsetForDataPoint(Visiblox.Charts.IChartSeries)
member.summary: For any given IDataPoint in an , get an offset to apply to the render position on the base axis, relative to that dictated by its actual base axis position.
member.param: The series the data point belongs to.
member.returns: An offset, represented as a double.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.IOffsetProvider.GetPerpendicularAxisOffsetForDataPoint(Visiblox.Charts.IChartSeries,Visiblox.Charts.IDataPoint,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: For a given IDataPoint on an , get its render position on the perpendicular axis.
member.param: The series the data point belongs to.
The data point to get the offset for.
If true, the height of the dataPoint itself will be included.
The render position with zoom is returned if true, without zoom otherwise.
member.returns: An offset, represented as a double.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.IOffsetProvider.GetBaseAxisOffsetGeometry(Visiblox.Charts.IChartSeries)
member.summary: For a given , get the offset that should act as the base 'path' on the base axis. This is used by to enable stacked areas.
member.param: The series to get the offset path for.
member.returns: A representing the series 'below' this series in a stacking context.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.IOffsetProvider.GetPerpendicularAxisOffsetGeometry(Visiblox.Charts.IChartSeries)
member.summary: For a given , get the offset that should act as the base 'path' on the perpendicular axis. This is used by to enable stacked areas.
member.param: The series to get the offset path for.
member.returns: A representing the series 'below' this series in a stacking context.

member.summary: Determines which axis should be used as the perpendicular axis for this series type.

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.IChartSeriesCommon.XRange
member.summary: Gets or sets the X range of the plotted series. This is a volatile object.
member.remarks: This may be the data series value range, or may be enlarged to account for the displayed width/height of points. For example the X range occupied by a column series is wider than the range of the data by half of the width of a column, on both maximum and minimum.
Do not change the properties on this object as it may be overwritten by the chart. Instead use Range to set a specific range.

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.IChartSeriesCommon.YRange
member.summary: Gets or sets the Y range of the plotted series. This is a volatile object.
member.remarks: This may be the data series value range, or may be enlarged to account for the displayed width/height of points. For example the Y range occupied by a bar series is wider than the range of the data by half of the width of a bar, on both maximum and minimum.
Do not change the properties on this object as it may be overwritten by the chart. Instead use Range to set a specific range.

member.summary: Defines members a class needs to implement in order to support selection. Both selection and highlighting of the entire class and selection of contained items is covered.

member.summary: Gets or sets whether the series can be highlighted by the user.

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.ISelectable.SelectionMode
member.summary: Gets or sets how the series supports selection.

remarks.para: The options are no selection, selection of the entire series, selection of a single individual point, or the selection of multiple points. These options are mutually exclusive.

Selection of points is generally via clicking on the individual point (see ) while selection of the entire series is via clicking on some part of the series (see ). (different series may choose to support this in different ways as appropriate).

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.ISelectable.SelectedItem
member.summary: Gets or sets the selected item. In case of multiple selected items, it refers to the first one.

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.ISelectable.SelectedItems
member.summary: Gets the list of selected points.

remarks.para: The selected points collection is altered by clicking on the points of a series, but can also be manipulated programmatically.

member.summary: Occurs when the currently selected item changes.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.LogicalAxisBase`2.GetDataValueAsAxisValue(`0)
member.summary: Converts a data value into an arbitrary double scale. This removes the complexity of converting to/from a render position which is handled in .
member.remarks: Converting a Data value to and from a Render position requires finding the data value relative to the current location of the left most Data value and the height/width of the chart. This method is provided to remove the need to implement this boiler plate code and allow an implementation to simply convert the Data value into an arbitrary double scale, which will be converted to a render position internally.
This is the inverse of .
member.example: A DateTime axis implementation could use the Ticks value of the DateTime passed through.
A double-based axis implementation could simply return the Data value as a double.
member.param: A data value.
member.returns: Arbitrary axis value corresponding to .

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.LogicalAxisBase`2.GetAxisValueAsDataValue(System.Double)
member.summary: Converts a value in the arbitrary double scale into a data value. This removes the complexity of converting to/from a render position which is handled in .
member.remarks: Converting a Data value to and from a Render position requires finding the data value relative to the current location of the left most Data value and the height/width of the chart. This method is provided to remove the need to implement this boiler plate code and allow an implementation to simply convert an arbitrary double scale into the Data value, which will be converted to a render position internally.
This is the inverse of .
member.example: A DateTime axis implementation could return the DateTime value of the number of Ticks passed through.
A double-based axis implementation could simply return the double as the Data value.
member.param: The value (in the axis specific axis range) to retrieve as a data value.
member.returns: Data value corresponding to .

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.BitmapManager
member.summary: Manages the collation of bitmaps from multiple s such that they share one bitmap and update when required.
member.remarks: When a raster series requires a render update, it must invalidate this BitmapManager, which will in turn ask all series sharing its bitmap to render, and push this rendered bitmap to the series responsible for display.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.DataPoint`2
member.summary: Represents a single-valued data point which is stored in the class.
member.remarks: DataPoint defines a two-dimensional (X and Y) point. It implements to allow the chart to respond to changes in the X or Y values dynamically. It does not, however, support multiple Y values. To use a data point with multiple Y values see . To create data points automatically from a data source via binding, see (this also supports multiple Y values).

member.summary: Represents a 3D data series

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.IDataSeries
member.summary: Represents a collection that contains points which can be plotted on a chart but makes no assumptions about the way in which that data is visually presented.

remarks.para: IDataSeries is used as the data source for all and the .
To create an IDataSeries bound to an existing data source, see , or to create an IDataSeries by directly constructing data points see .

member.remarks: Note when implementing this interface it is the responsibility of the implementation to ensure that the indexes contained in the INotifyCollectionChangedArgs when the CollectionChanged event is raised match up with the data returned from the GetEnumerator call such that the index 0 refers to the first element returned and index n refers to the (n+1)th element returned. Failure to correctly maintain this relationship this may cause unexpected behaviour during the addition or modification of data points at runtime.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.IDataSeries.GetSearchableSeries
member.summary: Get the searchable data series associated with this DataSeries. This can either be the series itself, or some internal series that handles the sorting and searching.

member.summary: Defines required members a series needs to implement in order to work within a . This interface represents a graphical depiction on the chart of a set of data (which in Visiblox Charts is an implementation of the interface).

remarks.para: defines an implementation of this interface, although it is not recommended to implement this class directly. is extended by two further classes which provide more specific series types. For implementing a new single series type, it is advised to extend , which also implements . For implementing a new multiple series type, it is advised to extend , which also implements .

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.DiscreteHeatPlotSeries
member.summary: Represents a discrete heat plot series. A discrete heat plot series requires an collection and renders the points in a grid. The number of distinct X values in the data series defines the number of columns in the grid and the number of distinct Y values defines the number of rows. Each point is rendered as a cell in the grid based on its X and Y value while the Z value defines the cell color.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.HeatPlotSeries
member.summary: Represents a heat plot series. A heat plot series requires an collection and renders each point as a spot. The size of each spot is defined by and and the colour is extracted by the Z value of the respective point. If the spots overlap, then the colour of the overlapping pixels will be a blend of all the individual colours.

member.summary: Gets or sets the gradient factor by which the center color fades towards the edge of each spot. Setting it to 1 will make each spot completely opaque (no gradient applied) while 0 will apply a smooth gradient from the center color to transparent. This is a Dependency Property.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.AutoSeriesGenerator
member.summary: AutoSeriesGenerator defines attached properties to allow for an IEnumerable holding collections of business objects to be bound to a , and have appropriate instances automatically generated and managed upon changes to this collection.

remarks.para: The XValuePath and YValuePath define binding paths to the properties on the business objects to use for the X and Y values of data points. The ChartSeriesProvider property is responsible for creating the instances for each collection. By default, this functionality is provided by , which accepts a string representation of the subclass to use. The TitlePath property identifies the binding path to the property to use for the title of a created series.

If the IEnumerable declared as the ItemsSource implements INotifyCollectionChanged, then AutoSeriesGenerator will subscribe to the CollectionChanged events fired and update the Chart series accordingly.

Rather than specifying X and Y bindings, one can alternatively provide a source collection which directly contains instances. Data points will thus not be created automatically, but one can still benefit from generation of .

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.BindableDataPoint
member.summary: Represents a data point with binding support, which is stored in the class.

remarks.para: Rather than being created directly, a BindableDataPoint is created by a automatically based on its source data collection.
The data point may be single or multiple-valued, as required.
When binding to a BindableDataPoint, it is possible to bind to properties of the source item via its DataContext.
If the bound source item does not implement IComparable, it will be wrapped in the adapter class which implements IComparable.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.BindableDataSeries
member.summary: Represents a data series with data binding support.

remarks.para: To create a BindableDataSeries set the , and the . BindableDataSeries can support binding to multiple Y values. In this case use the instead of to specify Y bindings. BindableDataSeries consists of objects. It creates and manages this collection automatically.
If you do not require the ability to bind to an existing data source, provides an alternate implementation constructing a list of data points directly.
BindableDataSeries implements a read-only IList of to allow for direct access to the BindableDataPoints.
If the XValueBinding or YValueBinding (and YValueBindings) are null at the time of rendering, an InvalidOperationException is thrown.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.DataSeries`2
member.summary: An consisting of a collection of DataPoint objects.
member.remarks: DataSeries fires PropertyChanged and CollectionChanged notifications when its data points are changed. DataSeries does not support binding. For a series with binding support see . DataSeries contains a SortedDataSeries by default. On construction, a DataSeries can be provided with a Comparison{IDataPoint} delegate that will be passed through to the SortedDataSeries. If there is no requirement to have a SortedDataSeries, the DataSeries can be constructed with a false parameter which will disable the maintenance of the SortedDataSeries. In this scenario, there is no need to provide the Comparison{IDataPoint} delegate.
member.typeparam: The X axis value type.
The Y axis value type.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.DefaultChartSeriesProvider
member.summary: A default implementation of , which always provides instances of the type passed upon instantiation.

remarks.para: Given a collection containing collections of business objects, this implementation of IChartSeriesProvider ensures that each collection will be represented by the same chart series type. member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.Legend
member.summary: Represents a chart legend rendered as a collection of instances each bound to a series.
member.remarks: Each has one legend, represented as a Legend object. The legend is never created nor modified by the chart user, but instead the chart adds and removes items to the legend based upon the series in the chart. The , , and properties of the may be used to alter the presentation of the legend.
member.example: The legend appearance may be customised by changing its template (by setting the property). The default template applied to the Legend is the following:

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.Primitives.DataPointYValuesConverter
member.summary: Gets a named Y value from an by indexing it with the given converter parameter.
member.remarks: This converter works around the limitation that in Silverlight 3, it is not possible to bind to an expression using an arbitrary indexer, and in Silverlight 4, there are still limitations on indexers in binding (must be an int or string, and no multiple indexers allowed). It may be useful to use a DataPointYValuesConverter when binding to a multi-valued data point, such as when defining a tooltip template.
member.example: The following XAML demonstrates the use of a DataPointYValuesConverter to access the High value of a multi-value data point.

member.summary: This class deals with the invalidation of objects and the en- and de-queuing of invalidation requests.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.Primitives.InvalidationHandler.RequestInvalidation(Visiblox.Charts.Primitives.IInvalidatable,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Request that the is invalidated at the next opportunity - note that this request will not be honoured if there is already a request pending for this requester.
member.param: The object to be invalidated.
If true requests from an already queued object will not be requeued, if false they are always requeued.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.Primitives.InvalidationHandler.CancelInvalidationRequest(Visiblox.Charts.Primitives.IInvalidatable)
member.summary: Cancel any pending invalidation requests for .
member.param: The object to have its invalidation request cancelled.

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.Primitives.InvalidationHandler.InvalidationsSuspended
member.summary: Determines whether invalidations are suspended. If set to true, no invalidations will occur until it is set to false again, at which point the invalidations will resume and occur at the next opportunity.

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.Primitives.InvalidationHandler.ForceImmediateInvalidate
member.summary: If set to true invalidations will be executed immediately rather than being en-queued for later execution.

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.Primitives.InvalidationHandler.ForceLayoutUpdateBeforeRendered
member.summary: If set to true LayoutUpdate will be invoked on any IInvalidatable which has not been rendered immediately after an element had has been invalidated via DoInvalidate.
member.remarks: One issue with the concept of deferred invalidation is that it can stall the layout mechanism, in that if an invalidation of an IInvalidatable results in an Invalidation of another IInvalidatable instance when layout is performed (e.g. a SizeChange is handler resulting in the invalidation of a related element), the invalidation of the related IInvalidatable occurs after the next Rendering event. As a result, the visuals are briefly rendered in an intermediate state. This property, when set to true, ensures that IInvalidatable instances have their layout updated immediately after invalidation until their Rendering property is set to true. The Rendering property is set to true on the first Rendering event after their initial invalidation request is made.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.Primitives.StringToDataSeriesConverter
member.summary: A type converter that converts a string into an .

remarks.para: The type of the x and y values are determined by the first valid point that is parsed. Any points that do not match these types will be ignored.
The type of points (DataPoint or MultiValuedDataPoint) are also determined by the first valid point that is parsed. Any points that do not match this type will be ignored.
s should be enclosed in round brackets '(data values)' and separated with a comma ','; (point1),(point2),(point3).
The X and Y values should be separated by a comma; x,y.
For s the Y values can be enclosed in square brackets '[data values]' and separated by a comma; (x,[y1,y2,y3,y4]).

para.b: The Characters '(),[]' should not be used as part of a data value.

remarks.para: If the string to be parsed does not conform the the expected format the class will try to parse any valid points it can. For example the data points (10,40), (50,30) and (60,90) will be parsed from the string:'(qwe)ert(10,40)(50,30)(0,3,5,7,9)(3,foo)(bar,3),,(60,90)'.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.CategoryRangeWithEffectiveLimits
member.summary: Represent a discrete range consisting of categories, bounded by a a , , and value, categories defined by .

remarks.para: The purpose of this range is to serve as the list of categories on a .

and are defined here to be the index bounds of collection. and however are double values (as these values need to be selected from a continuous value range to fully support the zoom functionality). and does the conversion between the discrete categories and the double values.

The and are always the last or first members of the collection. Setting them will therefore behave differently than in case of continuous ranges: if the value is not yet contained in, it will be added to the first/last position appropriately, otherwise the value will not be added and / will be left unchanged.
Categories can have a sort order of unsorted, ascending or descending, using and based on the natural ordering of IComparable members.

member.typeparam: The type of the values within this range.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.IRangeWithEffectiveLimits
member.summary: Defines a range of values bounded by a and . and values are used to define the range with zoom applied.

remarks.para: Defines a range used by to define its . and give the maximum and minimum data values within the range with the range applied.
and define an additional window within the boundaries representing the zoom on a continuous range.

The value range of ranges can be continuous or discrete. and represent the zoom within the continuous range. and represent the zoom within the discrete range and are converted from the and using . Since zooming happens on a continuous scale, we need a value which is in a continuous scale, for ease of use a discrete version of this value is also supplied. Other values can be mapped from continuous to discrete and vice versa in the and methods.
For continuous ranges these methods ( and ) do not contain extra logic as this conversion only has to be done for discrete ranges.

member.param: Range minimum
Range maximum

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.IRangeWithEffectiveLimits.ToDiscreteValueRange(System.IComparable)
member.summary: Maps (which value is from a continuous value range) to the value range of the range itself, which includes: , , and . For discrete ranges this means mapping the continuous value range used by to the discrete value range of the range itself. For continuous ranges no such conversion is needed - the continuous value can act as a discrete value and vice versa.
member.param: A value in the continuous value range.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.IRangeWithEffectiveLimits.ToContinuousValueRange(System.IComparable)
member.summary: Maps (which value is from the value range of the range itself) to the continuous value range used, which includes: and . For discrete ranges this means mapping the discrete value range of the range itself to the continuous value range. For continuous ranges no such conversion is needed - the discrete value can act as a continuous value and vice versa.
member.param: A value in the discrete value range.

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.CategoryRangeWithEffectiveLimits.ContinuousEffectiveMaximum
member.summary: Gets or sets the applied continuous maximum for the range. This is a double value (as it needs to have a continuous value range). This value is continuously being re-calculated by the axis, thus setting it externally is not recommended as it will have no effect.
member.remarks: The type of EffectiveMaximum used by this range is a double. Mapping is done by assigning 1.0 length to all categories and mapping the double value to the closest category. E.g. EffectiveMaximum set to 0.6 would mean it's mapped to the 2nd category (as [-0.5,0.5) is mapped to the 1st category and [0.5, 1.5) is mapped to the 2nd category).

member.remarks: The type of EffectiveMinimum used by this range is a double. Mapping is done by assigning 1.0 length to all categories and mapping the double value to the closest category. E.g. EffectiveMinimum set to 0.6 would mean it's mapped to the 2nd category (as [-0.5,0.5) is mapped to the 1st category and [0.5, 1.5) is mapped to the 2nd category).

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.PieChart
member.summary: Represents a pie chart. A PieChart has one DataSeries (which must be a DataSeries{IComparable, double}), a Title and a Legend. PieCharts are made up of a number of s.

remarks.para: The must be of type DataSeries{IComparable, double}, this is because a percentage must be calculated for each of the PieChart. It is only offered as to support binding.

Customizing the look of the PieChart can be done either by supplying a new or by specifying a completely new template for the pie pieces against . When setting a palette, that will contain a list of styles which will be cycled through for each pie piece created. The Palette allows for a list of styles to be created (with target type of ), specifying , and . It is also possible to set these properties for and . If using the template approach the template must contain a Grid named LayoutRoot and a Path named PiePiecePath. The Data and the RenderTransform properties for the PiePiecePath will be set by the render mechanism to render the correct shape with the correct rotation.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.PiePiece
member.summary: A PiePiece which represents a slice of a . The PiePiece has a notion of it's and it's which it uses to render.
member.remarks: Currently the only way to change the colour of the PiePieces within the is to use the . This is because the list of Pie Pieces is not available through the public API.

The notion of interaction is offered for individual pieces as well as the entire chart through and . When hovered over, the will be applied to this piece and will be set to true. When clicked on, the will be applied to this piece and will be set to true.
and are offered to allow for easy manipulation of the pie piece representation within the .

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.BandSeries
member.summary: Represents a band series where each point has a higher and lower value.

remarks.para: A band series by default consists of a straight line connecting all higher values in the series and a straight line connecting all lower values in the series. An area is present between these lines which may be styled.

When the lines cross, an InvertedAreaStyle is used to represent the inversion. When they re-cross, the normal AreaStyle is used again. By default the area fill is not visible, but can be enabled using the ShowArea property.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.ChartSingleSeriesBase
member.summary: ChartSeriesBase is an specialisation of , to define a singular chart series.

remarks.para: Selection is supported on a singular chart series. The dependency property identifies the different selection modes available - such as selection of an entire series, a data point or multiple points. As such, the , and properties provide access to the selection state. Highlighting is also supported, with the property identifying if the series is highlighted. The and dependency properties allow for the selected and highlighted states to be styled.
ChartSeriesBase is responsible for overriding the default and calculations, and instead will return ranges based upon the values in the held by this chart series.

In order to implement a new singular series type, it is advised to extend this class, rather than the parent as this class provides common singular-series functionality that would otherwise have to be implemented on each series; such as selection.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.ChartSeriesBase
member.summary: Represents the base class for implementations, defining common behaviour held for all Cartesian chart series.

remarks.para: A series is associated with a pair of axes against which the data is plotted, represented by its and properties (although in most cases these do not have to be set explicitly).
It is advised to inherit one of the two specialised versions of this class. For defining a singular series, consider inheriting from . For defining a multiple series, consider inheriting from .

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.ChartSeriesCommonBase
member.summary: Represents the base class for implementations, defining common behaviour held for all Visiblox Charts series types.

remarks.para: This class is responsible for providing properties relating to styling and basic handling of the of the series.

A class inheriting from ChartSeriesCommonBase represents a particular type of series which is drawn on a subclass. A chart series defines how data is presented on the chart; the data to display is given by its property.
ToolTip support is implemented in this class, and can be enabled via the property. Each series defines a default tooltip format, but tooltips can also be customised as described in the example below.
Styling: to style a series, do this by either setting its style specific properties or by setting . Using the Style property to style the series is not advised, use NormalStyle instead.

A trackball can be added to a series by adding a to the chart. ChartSeriesBase supports the trackball implementation by providing templating and styling support for trackballs, with a suitable default defined for each series, again see the example below.

By default, no range calculations are performed at this level - and calls to and at this level in the hierarchy will return null. Instead, concrete range calculations are performed by specialised classes like , and .

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.ChartSeriesBase.IsPointRenderableInternal(Visiblox.Charts.IDataPoint)
member.summary: Determines whether the point can be rendered on the canvas. Subclasses using multiple Y valued data points or having other constraints should override IsPointRenderableInternal to enforce validity.

remarks.para: This base implementation checks the point's X value and its minimum Y value, which in both the case of single and multi-valued data points should indicate that the point is likely to be renderable. Subclasses may wish to override this to perform additional or alternative checks, such as the multiple Y values used by the series.

Series implementations should not render points for which IsPointRenderableInternal returns false; when extending or other provided series, beware that these classes will filter out points deemed un-renderable by this method.

member.param: Point to check
member.returns: Whether the point is displayable

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.ChartSingleSeriesBase.ResolveStyles(System.Windows.Style)
member.summary: Resolve the series styling based on the requirements of the given series. This means converting the style of the series into something that can be applied to the Style property of the visual elements. For example, the PointSize, PointStroke and PointStrokeThickness properties might all be converted to a style with TargetType Ellipse and property setters for Width, Height, Stroke and StrokeThickness. The method will be called multiple times for each state Normal, Selected, Highlighted and SelectedHighlighted, passing in the style to use as the basis for restyling.
member.param: The style on which to base the StateSpecificStyle. In the event of Normal styling this will be null.
member.returns: The style specific to a single state.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.BarOrColumnSeriesBase
member.summary: Base class for and .

remarks.para: and are essentially the same thing, but with X and Y axis swapped round. Almost all the functionality therefore is in this base class.
Below we shall talk about column charts, but this applies equally to bar charts.

When a column series is displayed on a chart, the width of its columns are calculated based upon the spacing of the supplied data. Narrower columns can be achieved by altering : by default this is 0.75, at 1 all columns will be touching, while at 0.5 the columns will be half this size (resulting in the space between columns being the same size as the columns themselves).

If multiple column series are displayed on the same chart, they are displayed together. The series are all sized and spaced so that at each data point, a group of columns is displayed together, the leftmost column for the first column series on the chart and the rightmost for the last.
Where one column series has some missing X values, the series will be spaced and sized as if these were 0.

The OffsetProvider property identifies that BarOrColumnSeriesBase implements and can therefore be used in a stacking context. This property is set to the containing , such as or to perform offset calculations and apply them during rendering. It is not necessary to set this property.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.IStackableChartSeries
member.summary: IStackableChartSeries represents the concept that an can be used within a stacking context, and defines the necessary functionality in order for a series to interact with an .

remarks.para: An which also implements IStackableChartSeries holds a reference to an . This OffsetProvider, which in the stacking context is of type will hold a collection of series in order to calculate offset values that should be applied to data points in this series. Interaction with this OffsetProvider allows for this series to access and apply such offsets during the rendering procedure.

Note that the fast rendering mode is only efficient under a restricted set of circumstances depending on whether hardware or software rendering is used and whether anti-aliasing is enabled or not. member.summary: Base class for series with multi value data points (.

member.summary: Creates the visual representation of the logical point.
member.remarks: Note that this method will only be called for points deemed renderable by , consider overriding to enforce an appropriate condition for this series.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.MultiValueSeriesBase.UpdatePoint(System.Windows.FrameworkElement,Visiblox.Charts.IDataPoint)
member.summary: Updates the visual that is the representation of the logical point to reflect the new value of . Implementation is optional.

remarks.para: Implementation of is optional for efficiency. If UpdatePoint returns true, this indicates the point has been updated successfully. If this method returns false, as in the base implementation, the existing point is removed, and is used instead to create its replacement.
Note that this method will only be called for points deemed renderable by , consider overriding to enforce an appropriate condition for this series.

member.param: The existing visual representation of the point.
The logical point.
member.returns: True if was updated and false otherwise.

member.returns: The visual element to be plotted on the screen.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.ChartMultipleSeriesBase
member.summary: ChartMultipleSeriesBase is a specialisation of , to define a chart series whose rendering is dependent upon a set of data series - such as stacked series.

remarks.para: The dependency property identifies a which contains the that are dependent upon each other. ChartMultipleSeriesBase listens to the CollectionChanged, DataSeriesCollectionChanged and SeriesPropertyChangedAggregate events of each series in this collection, to ensure that all series are invalidated upon a change of one series.
ChartMultipleSeriesBase is responsible for overriding the default and calculations, and instead will return an aggregate range based upon the ranges of each individual .
The dependency property identifies a custom palette that can be applied as default styling to the series in the collection property.

In order to implement a new multiple series type, it is advised to extend this class, rather than the parent , as this class provides common singular-series functionality that would otherwise have to be implemented on each series.
The dependency property applies the stacking method that should be applied in a stacking context.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.IChartMultipleSeries
member.summary: IChartMultipleSeries is a specialisation of . A multiple chart series holds a collection of , representing that the drawing of these IChartSingleSeries is dependent upon other series within the IChartMultipleSeries' property.

remarks.para: The property of IChartMultipleSeries holds a . The series that are contained in this collection are related. For stackable series, for example, the series are related because their render positions are dependent on other series in this collection.
The abstract class implements some common functionality, so it is advised that, when implementing a new multiple series type, that class is extended rather than implementing this interface directly.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.IChartMultipleSeries.AssociateSeries
member.summary: Associate series in the collection by setting common properties.

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.IChartMultipleSeries.Series
member.summary: A of , whose drawing depends on the other series in the collection.

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.IChartMultipleSeries.Palette
member.summary: Gets or sets the palette for the series.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.IStackedOffsetProvider
member.summary: Represents an offset provider which is to be used to stack .

remarks.para: In order to perform stacking, multiple are held within the Series property of an instance, which itself is added to a 's Series property. IStackedOffsetProvider defines additional behaviour to be used when series are rendered within a stacking context.

The stacking method to be used for rendering is determined by the property. IStackedOffsetProvider declares the GetOneHundredPercentProportion method for when the StackingMode property is set to StackingMode.HundredPercent. In 100% stacking, the base axis value of a data point (X for column and line series, Y for bar series) is not used for stacking - instead the percentage of the sum of all base axis values at point is used. This method returns that percentage.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.IStackedOffsetProvider.GetOneHundredPercentProportion(Visiblox.Charts.IDataPoint)
member.summary: For one-hundred percent stacking, the 'value' of each data point is not its plot position. Instead, it is turned into a percentage based on the proportion of its value with respect to other stacked series. For a given on an , calculate this proportional value, that can be used to calculate the render position of the IDataPoint.
member.param: The data point to get the proportional value for.
member.returns: The proportional value, represented as a double.

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.IStackedOffsetProvider.StackingMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the property identifying the stacking method used to arrange and render stacked series.
