If true the point's dimensions will be included in the offset, otherwise only the offset up to the point will be returned.

member.returns: The offset for the data point and series.

member.remarks: This method computes a result that is used by GetPerpendicularAxisOffsetForDataPoint, which simply converts that result to a render position.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.IDependentChartSeries
member.summary: Interface for series that depend on the other series within the same chart when drawing themselves.
member.remarks: An example is stacked bar series: in order to plot the next stacked bar part, the series has to know where the previous series where plotted in order to draw on top of them.

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.IDependentChartSeries.ChartSeriesCollection
member.summary: Gets or sets the other series that are plotted on the same chart.
member.remarks: This property is set by the chart and used by the dependent chart series.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.LineSeries
member.summary: Represents a line series.

remarks.para: A LineSeries by default consists of straight lines connecting its data points. To indicate the location of each data point, the property can be set to true, or to fill in the area below the line the property can be set to true. It is also possible to set the property to false to disable the connecting lines (a scatter chart effect can be created by turning lines off and points on).
If is true, LineSeries supports selection of points.

The OffsetProvider property identifies that LineSeries implements and can therefore be used in a stacking context. This property is set to the containing , such as to perform offset calculations and apply them during rendering. It is not necessary to set this property.

In order to render the areas of stacked line series, the CloseEndPoints method will call either CloseEndPointsAtBase, or CloseEndPointsAtLine, depending upon the position of a Line Series within the stack. These alter the area PathFigure to ensure it only fills the correct amount of space. CloseEndPointsAtBase and CloseEndPointsAtLine can be overridden, if necessary, should the path of a line not be a direct straight line.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.SeriesRenderManager
member.summary:
Implementations of that provide FastPathRendering should hold a reference to an instance of this class.
Properties that affect whether fast-path rendering is possible or not should call in their OnPropertyChanged handler. By default SelectionMode is one of those properties. If other properties also affect fast-path rendering, override so that they are taken in to consideration.
When fast-path rendering becomes possible/impossible is called. In this base implementation it invalidates the series but this can be overridden.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.StackedBarSeries
member.summary: A StackedBarSeries holds a collection of , applying stacking logic so that the final render positions of each bar is calculated with respect to other series in the collection.

remarks.para: StackedBarSeries enforces that the collection only holds chart series, and will throw an InvalidCastException if this rule is violated. StackedBarSeries is unable to perform stacking when the X axis is a category axis, and an ArgumentException will be thrown if this rule is violated.

As StackedBarSeries is an , the OffsetProvider of each of the BarSeries in the Series collection is set to this instance, to allow each BarSeries to obtain its offset positions and proportional values, according to the stacking context declared in the property.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.StaircaseSeries
member.summary: Represents a staircase series.

remarks.para: A StaircaseSeries consists of vertical and horizontal lines connecting points. By default, the line between two points travels horizontally to the right and then vertically. In other words, the position of the step (up or down) in the line is on the right of the region between points. The StepPosition can also be set to Left or Center.
Example: if is set to Right and the series contains two points (1,1) and (3,3) then a series of horizontal and vertical lines will be drawn with corners at (1,1), (3,1), (3,3).

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.SimplePalette
member.summary: Class that allows simpler definition of palettes.

remarks.para: By defining and , the class takes care of generating the list of styles, that would otherwise need to be defined by hand when using .

Two steps are required defining a palette. First, the need to be assigned. The members of this collection should be one style per different TargetTypes. If unset a default template set will be loaded instead.

The palette will generate a new style based on the provided templates for each colour provided, replacing any brushes in the styles it finds against which the attached property ReplaceBrush is set to true with a with the specified colour.

If you are using Silverlight and you want to use the standard Visiblox Charts styles but define your own colours you can do that by adding our default styles to the application resources by adding the following to your App.xaml file:

You can then set to the {StaticResource DefaultStyleTemplates} to get the standard styles for all series types and add your definition of the property (either by specifying a ColorCollection or if not on WP7 by using the built-in string converter and supplying a comma separated list of colors in XAML, e.g. #FFFF0000,#FF00FF00,#FF0000FF).

Note that because of the way Styles are merged it is not possible to use ReplaceBrush in a style which is later used as a BasedOn reference for a sub-Style. The attached property is not preserved across the merge, meaning you will need to re-define the setter in the sub-Style and re-specify the attached property. Note also that due to a restriction in Windows Phone 7, it is not possible to use a ReplaceBrush attached property on a setter for a CoreDependencyProperty on that platform.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.Zoom
member.summary: Represents a zoom in one dimension as a and .
member.remarks:
The zoomed area of a is represented by a pair of Zoom objects - one for and one for (see ). When multiple axes are used (, and/or ) the Zoom is referenced if the axis is not null, otherwise the Zoom is referenced.
Each Zoom is defined using these terms:
relates to the scale of the axis as a multiplier of its original size, by default this is 1.0. Setting the scale to 0.5 will result in the axis showing half as much data, creating an apparent 'zoom in'. Setting the scale to 2 will result in the axis showing twice as much data, creating an apparent 'zoom out'.
relates to the offset along the axis as a multiplier of its original size, by default this is 0.0. Setting this value to 0.5 will result in the viewport moving along the axis half the width of the chart in the positive direction (right for a horizontal axis, upward for a vertical axis).
member.example: Creating a chart in XAML which is zoomed in to the top right quarter of the chart:

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.AnnotationBase
member.summary: Base class for annotations. An annotation is an object placed on top of a chart, either programmatically or by user interaction. Depending on the type of annotation, this may later be moved, resized or otherwise altered.

remarks.para: An annotation contains a list of data points that determines its position and size. The points are values on the and . Thus the annotation is generally anchored to the charted data, and will maintain its relative position on zooming, panning, altering the chart range, etc. However, it is also possible to create annotations which are displayed at a fixed screen location.

There are two ways to add annotations to the chart: they may be placed by drawing on the plot area via AnnotationBehaviour (not available on Windows Phone), or constructed directly and added to the collection.

The display (and redisplay) of an annotation is accomplished by its method. An annotation should call to display itself initially on construction. An invalidate is also triggered when the axis effective range has changed.

Interaction with the annotation is controlled by the property: if this property is false, interaction with the annotation element is not enabled, including resizing, dragging and deleting, and the element will be transparent to the mouse pointer.

The of an annotation determines what happens when an annotation is clicked on. If is Drag, clicking and dragging on an annotation will move it. If is Delete, clicking on the annotation will delete it (without confirmation, although the cursor will change over the annotation to indicate deletion). Note that deletion may also be accomplished programmatically by simply removing the annotation from the collection.

To allow for resizing or altering the shape of an annotation, a should be added for each control point. Usually this will be the points in , but this is not enforced, and an annotation may have more or fewer grippers. A gripper is added via , which takes an , and displays an interactable "gripper" on the chart: when the gripper is dragged to a new location, the data point is updated to the new coordinates. If the point was contained in , this will result in an , otherwise the annotation will have to listen for the point's property changed event and take appropriate action.

An annotation consists of an and a . The is the representation of the actual annotation, not including any editing/interaction elements, and is able to be styled via . The represents the element the user will click and drag by mouse interaction. When the mouse is not over the annotation, the is used, which should hide the , but may provide an enlarged area for interaction (e.g. to make clicking on a line easier). The is used when the mouse is over the annotation, or is dragging it, and should indicate visually the element is active by highlighting it. It is advised to ensure that these styles have roughly the same size to ensure correct rendering.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.IAnnotation
member.summary: Represents an annotation added on top of the chart. This is an object placed on a chart, either programmatically or by user interaction. Depending on the type of annotation, this may later be moved, resized or otherwise altered.
member.remarks: forms the base class for annotation implementations, and implements a large deal of the interaction behaviour an annotation will require in most circumstances. In the majority of cases it should be unnecessary to implement IAnnotation directly.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.IAnnotation.Invalidate
member.summary: Invoked in order to re-construct the visual layout of this annotation.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.IAnnotation.Init(Visiblox.Charts.Chart,System.Windows.Controls.Grid)

summary.para: Invoked by the chart when an annotation is initially added.

remarks.para:
The annotation is expected to register to and handle the following events in this method:
event handling when or have changed.
and PropertyChanged events and handling when ActualRange has changed
When implementing the interface directly, be aware that Init will be called multiple times on the annotation.

member.param: The chart containing the annotation.

The container for the annotations. Note that this is not drawn on directly, the annotation is placed in this container by the chart. However this may be useful to e.g. find out the size of the plot area.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.IAnnotation.DeInit

summary.para: Invoked by the chart when the annotation is to be removed.
The annotation should de-register from the events registered in the Init method.

member.remarks: Implementations should be aware that DeInit may be called multiple times, and should not raise an exception in this case.

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.IAnnotation.Points
member.remarks: The last point in Points will be used to resize the annotation on placement by . Thus the points should be ordered in such a way as this is a natural point to resize the annotation when defining it with a drag operation.

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.IAnnotation.ClickMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the action to be taken on clicking on the annotation (dragging or deletion).
member.remarks: If interaction is not enabled via changing this property has no effect.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.IAnnotationFactory
member.summary: Represents a factory which allows the creation of annotations, to be used by .

remarks.para: An implementation of should return a new when the method is called. This method is supplied with the initial click point of the , and should create an annotation on that point. If appropriate the annotation should be (close to) zero size on that point, and resizable during the creation operation of .

The annotation factory may always return the same type of annotation, or may return different types of annotation based on some external factor. is provided, which allows the creation of all the included annotation types via a property controlling which type is created.
To use an , the property should be set on an .

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.DiscontinuousDateTimeAxis
member.summary: Represents an Axis for data where there may be dates and times missing, such as weekends, holidays or non-business hours.

remarks.para: The result of these exclusions is as if one were to cut out each missing section of a normal and paste these together along the joins. Data is charted continuously as if these missing dates/times did not exist.

The general operation of the discontinuous axis is by mapping "real world" DateTime values onto compressed DateTime values, where all discontinuities have been removed. The basis of this compression is the first non-excluded time after the ActualRange.Minimum. Series may be drawn across these discontinuities without issue, however in the case of data points which fall within the discontinuity, these will not be rendered. It is not recommended to chart a data series with points falling on the discontinuity, or with a range minimum or maximum within a discontinuity.

The setup of the time periods to exclude from the axis is accomplished by a . The axis contains a property, which is used with its range, which must be a . To obtain a suitable range with the axis's , the 's method can be used.

member.example:
The following XAML defines a DiscontinuousDateTimeAxis where the hours charted are Monday-Friday, 08.30-18.00:
The following XAML defines a DiscontinuousDateTimeAxis where the hours charted are Monday 06.00 - Friday 20.00:

member.summary: Overrides to filter out any major tick values falling on a discontinuity (via ).
member.remarks: Customisation of tick generation can be implemented by either overriding this method to generate ticks from scratch or to further modify filtered values, or overriding to change the way the base ticks are filtered.
member.returns: A list of major tick values not falling on discontinuities.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.DiscontinuousDateTimeAxis.GetMinorTickValues
member.summary: Overrides to filter out any major tick values falling on a discontinuity (via ).
member.remarks: Customisation of tick generation can be implemented by either overriding this method to generate ticks from scratch or to further modify filtered values, or overriding to change the way the base ticks are filtered.
member.returns: A list of minor tick values not falling on discontinuities.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.DiscontinuousDateTimeAxis.FilterDateValues(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.DateTime})
member.summary: Filters out a list of date times to exclude any dates falling in discontinuities.
member.remarks: FilterDateValues is used by and to filter the ticks generated by the base tick generation algorithm. Customisation of tick generation can be implemented by either overriding this method to change the way the ticks are filtered, or overriding and to generate ticks directly.
member.param: The date times to filter.
member.returns: A filtered list of the parameter date time list.

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.DiscontinuousDateTimeAxis.DiscontinuityProvider
member.summary: The used by the axis to define included and excluded times.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.DailyHoursModeProvider
member.summary: Represents an which calculates discontinuities on a based on a "daily hours" mode of working (e.g. Monday-Friday, 08.30-18.00). Daily start and end hours are given along with a list of excluded days of the week, and these periods repeat indefinitely on a weekly basis, along with a fixed list of non-repeating ignored dates.

remarks.para: The included period each day is from to , but any days in are excluded entirely. The defined included/excluded periods repeat indefinitely on a weekly basis. Furthermore, any dates in are also excluded entirely (once only).

member.example: The following XAML defines a DiscontinuousDateTimeAxis where the hours charted are Monday-Friday, 08.30-18.00:

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.IDiscontinuityProvider
member.summary: Defines operations for calculating the included and excluded parts of a .
member.remarks: An provides operations to allow the conversion between real world DateTime values and the continuous compressed DateTime world of included times. Given two dates, the actual charted time between them is given by , while conversely given a date and a period of actual charted time, calculates the date resulting from this addition.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.IDiscontinuityProvider.IsIncluded(System.DateTime)
member.summary: Determines whether the given is included in the charted period or excluded (in a discontinuity). Series points, axis labels etc. will not be plotted for values where this method returns false.
member.param: Date to check.
member.returns: True if is included and false otherwise.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.IDiscontinuityProvider.GetIncludedTimeBetween(System.DateTime,System.DateTime)
member.summary: Computes the continuous included time period between and . This is the time between the two dates exclusive of any discontinuities.
member.remarks: Implementers should note that may be equal to or before . In the latter case a negative time should be returned. Also note that the parameters may be dates which are not themselves included.
member.param: Start of the period.
End of the period.
member.returns: The time period included between the specified extents.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.IDiscontinuityProvider.AddIncludedTime(System.DateTime,System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Computes the resulting date given by adding the continuous period to .
member.remarks: The time period does not include any discontinuities, so any discontinuous periods following must be skipped over when adding . Note that when start is an included time, the following equation should hold: GetIncludedTimeBetween(start, AddIncludedTime(start, time)) == time. Implementers should note that may be a negative time period, in which case the resulting date should still be the result of adding this negative period.
member.param: Start of the period.
Time to add (in continuous, included hours).
member.returns: The result of the addition.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.IDiscontinuityProvider.FindNearestIncludedDate(System.DateTime,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Calculates the nearest DateTime to the given which is included (i.e. does not fall in a discontinuity).
member.remarks: If is included this method should always return this value unchanged. However if the parameter does not fall in an included period, the parameter indicates whether the nearest date before or after it should be returned.
member.param: Date to check.
Whether to search forward or backward.
member.returns: The nearest date in the appropriate direction to which is included in the charted periods.

member.name: E:Visiblox.Charts.IDiscontinuityProvider.ValueConversionChanged
member.summary: Raised to indicate the conversions between the worlds of real and compressed DateTime values have changed, for example because a new discontinuity has been added to the provider's configuration. This will cause an event.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.NonRepeatingDiscontinuityProvider
member.summary: Represents an which calculates discontinuities on a based on a given set of discontinuous periods. This is intended as the basis for providers implementing more specific logic: see and for more directly usable examples of this.

remarks.para: This provider has a list of , which are given as a , specifying the start and end dates/times of the discontinuity.

See for a version of this class that implements repeating discontinuities. NonRepeatingDiscontinuityProvider can be constructed as an adaptor to an existing , resulting in date calculations which exclude a date if it would be excluded by either provider independently. For example, a can be adapted to also cut out holiday dates in addition to the regularly repeating excluded periods.

member.example: The following example illustrates how this class can be used along with .

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.WeeklyHoursModeProvider
member.summary: Represents an which calculates discontinuities on a based on a "weekly hours" mode of working (e.g. Monday 06.00 - Friday 20.00). Weekly start and end times are given, and these repeat indefinitely on a weekly basis, along with a fixed list of non-repeating ignored dates.

remarks.para: The included period each week is from on to on . It is permissible to give a weekly period which starts later in the week than it ends, as the weekly period simply spans two calendar weeks. The defined included/excluded periods repeat indefinitely on a weekly basis. Furthermore, any dates in are excluded entirely.

member.example: The following XAML defines a DiscontinuousDateTimeAxis where the hours charted are Monday 06.00 - Friday 20.00:

member.summary: Represents an which calculates discontinuities on a based on a given set of discontinuous periods within a week, repeating indefinitely. This is intended as the basis for providers implementing more specific logic: see and for more directly usable examples of this.
member.remarks: This provider has a list of , which are given as a - a pair of offsets from the start of the week (defined as midnight on Sunday morning). The calculation of this class is such that calculations spanning many weeks should be about as efficient as those spanning only one week.
See for a version of this class that implements non-repeating discontinuities, and can also be composed with another .
member.example: The following example illustrates how this class can be used along with .

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.FilteredDataSeries
member.summary: FilteredDataSeries is a data series adapter that permits the series to filter-out data points in response to changes in the chart axis. Typically this would be used to increase the density of the data points as the user zooms in, revealing more detailed data, applying data sampling algorithms or restricting the data series content to what is currently visible in the chart's view port. The algorithm for choosing the data points is pluggable in the form of a strategy, .
member.remarks: If either of the chart axes do not have an explicit Range set, the scale will be selected automatically to match the extents of the data series. With the FilteredDataSeries, change in the filtered data range might result in sudden changes of the axis range if the application of the strategy affects the data extents. Using will cause the FilteredDataSeries to set explicit ranges covering full range of the unfiltered data on either axis if it does not already have an explicit range

should not be set manually. Any subclass of will automatically set itself to any instance of IChartSeriesAwareDataSeries. You only need to set ChartSeries if you are implementing your own chart series without extending .

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.DynamicFilterStrategy.FilterStrategies
member.summary: The filter strategies to apply at different zoom levels. This must not be null. This list may be resorted and the first entry (i.e. that with the largest zoom scale) will be used to cover all zoom scales up to but not including the next smallest zoom scale defined. Note that dynamic changes to this list will not be automatically applied until the next event that could cause a change in the filter strategy (e.g. a zoom level change or an initialisation event)

member.summary: Determines whether to filter based on the X axis' or the Y axis' zoom level. Defaults to X axis.

member.summary: This implementation of maybe be used in conjunction with a to filter out the points that will be rendered on the same pixel, or very close to an existing data point. member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.IterativeEndPointFitFilterStrategy
member.summary: An implementation of the Ramer-Douglas-Peucker algorithm. In brief, this filter preserves the overall shape of a series but leaves out fine-grained detail. It does this by recursively omitting datapoints that would be rendered too far from the line drawn between two end points.

member.summary: Computes to mapping of tolerance to pixels. By default the tolerance is mapped to pixels 1:1 but this method may be overridden to alter the way that mapping is done.
member.param: The tolerance to apply.
member.returns: The number of pixels represented by that tolerance.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.WindowedFilterStrategy
member.summary: An implementation of a filter strategy for the which deals with exposing only the currently visible data. This allows for very large data series without needing to render all the data every time.
member.remarks: Note that this strategy requires that the original data series is sorted (by X or 'X then Y') - it must either implement, or contain an implementation of ISearchableSeries. Data will be returned in the order specified by the original order but points inside the current window, positioned subsequent to a point outside the upper edge of the window in the original series will not be included in the window.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.IRadialAxis
member.summary: Represents a radial chart axis.

remarks.para: A is rendered on the plot area of a . It has the responsibility to render ticks, grid lines and labels, however it's the responsibility of the to calculate the render positions of this elements and pass this information to methods responsible for the actual rendering on this interface.

The also responsible for calculations converting between data values and values used by to calculate the render position. If the of the axis is horizontal, the method returns this information, if it is vertical, the returns it.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.RadialAxisBase`1
member.summary: Provides a base implementation of .

remarks.para: See for a discussion of the general responsibilities of a radial axis.
provides a base axis implementation which handles the logic required to render an axis. In particular RadialAxisBase handles rendering of the ticks, grid lines and labels.

To provide a new axis implementation, a subclass must implement and to convert data values to angles or a ratio on the Y axis. It must also implement and to specify what spacing ticks, labels and grid lines are given. Other virtual methods are provided for further customisation.
If an invalid is supplied, the will remain the same. A null will cause the to be auto-calculated.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.RadialChart
member.summary: Represents a Visiblox Charts radial chart.

remarks.para: A radial chart takes care of generating all its components needed for display, the developer only has to add one or more to its collection.
The is the outer axis of the chart. The is represented by the spokes inside the chart.
Drawing of the axes can be controlled with the following properties:

item.description: Can be or . Results in X gridlines drawn as straight or circular lines respectively.
Increases the size of the empty circle in the middle of the chart.

remarks.para: Positioning of the axis labels can be set with the following properties:

item.description: Changes the distance that the X labels are rendered from the edge of the chart.

Can be or . Changing this results in the Y labels being drawn on either side of the chart, with lines connecting to the values. Changing results in the distance from the chart that these labels are drawn.

remarks.para: Styling the axes (their gridlines, ticks) and their labels can be done at the axis level, see for information on this.

RadialChart is designed to be fully customizable. The most important customization possibilities are the following:
Axis - The RadialChart always has one and . Axes are automatically created based on the type of data in the series but they can be programmatically assigned or re-assigned as well.
Styling - Both the RadialChart container and its components can be fully styled using styling related properties. RadialChart allows the styling of the series in various ways. Styling related properties can be set on the individual series, or the property can be used to define a palette and apply it to the chart. Specifying style related properties on the individual series has the highest precedence, this followed by specifying the NormalStyle, finally by declaring a custom Palette. If none of these are specified, the default Chart Palette will be applied to the series.

example.para:
Create a simple chart with a single radial line series:
Example output:

Customizing the RadialChart can be done through either the style related properties or by changing its layout via setting the property and changing its control template. By default the following template is applied to the radial chart. Use this as a base for changing the radial chart's control template.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.RadialChartSeriesBase
member.summary: Represents the base class for implementations.

remarks.para: A series is also associated with a pair of axes against which the data is plotted, represented by its and properties (although in most cases these do not have to be set explicitly).
When styling the series, do not set the Style property directly, instead assign the style to be used to the property. To style the highlighted and selected state, assign styles to the and properties.
ToolTip support is implemented in this class, and can be enabled via the property. Each series defines a default tooltip format, but tooltips can also be customised as described in the example below.
Styling: to style a series, do this by either setting its style specific properties or by setting . Using the Style property to style the series is not advised, use NormalStyle instead.

example.para: ToolTips can be templated via the property, and styled via the property. The default ToolTip templates for line series and candlestick series are shown below. The line series tooltip template can be used as a base for changing the template for a series with single-valued data points, and similarly the Candlestick series tooltip template can be used as a base for changing the template for a series with multi-valued data points.

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.RadialChartSeriesBase.IsPointRenderableInternal(Visiblox.Charts.IDataPoint)
member.summary: Determines whether the point can be rendered on the canvas. Subclasses using multiple Y valued data points or having other constraints should override IsPointRenderableInternal to enforce validity.

remarks.para: This base implementation checks the point's X value and its minimum Y value, which in both the case of single and multi-valued data points should indicate that the point is likely to be renderable. Subclasses may wish to override this to perform additional or alternative checks, such as the multiple Y values used by the series.

Series implementations should not render points for which IsPointRenderableInternal returns false; when extending or other provided series, beware that these classes will filter out points deemed unrenderable by this method.

member.param: Point to check.
member.returns: Whether the point is displayable.

member.summary: Represents a radial linear axis which is used to display numeric values.

remarks.para: This class represents an axis whose value type is numeric, represented by s, with a linear scale.

This is the default radial axis type which the chart will create automatically where the data is numeric, but will often be explicitly created by the chart user in order to set the various axis properties.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.RadialLineSeries
member.summary: Represents a radial line series.

remarks.para: A RadialLineSeries by default consists of straight lines connecting its data points. To indicate the location of each data point, the property can be set to true, or to fill in the area below the line the property can be set to true. It is also possible to set the property to false to disable the connecting lines (a scatter chart effect can be created by turning lines off and points on).
When styling the chart, do not use the Style setter, instead set , or . See on details of this.
Styling of the series can be done by setting the , , , properties or the , or style properties.
If is true, RadialLineSeries supports selection of points.

To set the stroke and stroke thickness, set the and properties on this class. This is a Dependency Property.

member.summary: Gets or sets the point style. The Style should have a TargetType of Shape. Fill, Stroke and StrokeThickness setters should not be defined in this style when using the default palette, as this will be overridden by the PointFill, PointStroke and PointStrokeThickness dependency properties defined in this palette. This is a Dependency Property.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.DiscontinuousDateTimeRangeWithEffectiveLimits
member.summary: Represents the range of a (a range of DateTime values with discontinuities (excluded periods).

remarks.para: The DiscontinuousDateTimeRangeWithEffectiveLimits implements the conversion between the "real world" of actual dates/times and the continuous compressed world of included times. It does this via the and methods (where here the "discrete" value range is in fact the discontinuous one), based on the provided .
To use the effective minimum/maximum values in "real-world" DateTimes, the following method can be used: axis.ActualRange.ToDiscreteValueRange(axis.ActualRange.EffectiveMinimum).

member.name: P:Visiblox.Charts.DiscontinuousLineSeries.AllowFastPathRendering
member.summary: Gets or sets whether this series should attempt to use fast rendering mode. Note that the fast rendering mode is only efficient under a restricted set of circumstances depending on whether hardware or software rendering is used and whether anti-aliasing is enabled or not. Even if this property is set to true, the implementation is series specific. Enabling should not change the behaviour of the series in any way other than how it is rendered and potential minor visual differences. This is a Dependency Property.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.TemplatedLineSeries
member.summary: Represents a line series whose points can be templated.

remarks.para: Templating is done by setting . This template will be used to render all points on the chart. If and/or templates are set, these will be used when rendering selected or highlighted points.

The legend is displayed using and scaling it appropriately. Therefore even if creating the points of the series programmatically, without using , this value still needs to be set in order to display an element on the legend. The above described process can be ignored if directly setting the control template.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.TemplatedSeries
member.summary: Represents a series in which each point is a templatable control.

remarks.para: Setting will set the template for the normal points. Setting sets the template for selected points, setting sets the template for highlighted points.

To create points programmatically, with data based on the data point, inherit from the class and override (for creating a point) and (for updating an existing point). By default a object is created by .
The legend item is displayed using . If more customization is needed than just specifying the legend item, set the control template.

member.name: T:Visiblox.Charts.RasterStaircaseSeries
member.summary: Represents a staircase series.

remarks.para: A StaircaseSeries consists of vertical and horizontal lines connecting points. By default, the line between two points travels horizontally to the right and then vertically. In other words, the position of the step (up or down) in the line is on the right of the region between points. The StepPosition can also be set to Left or Center.
Example: if is set to Right and the series contains two points (1,1) and (3,3) then a series of horizontal and vertical lines will be drawn with corners at (1,1), (3,1), (3,3).

member.name: M:Visiblox.Charts.RasterStaircaseSeries.CreateSteppedRenderPoints(System.Collections.Generic.List{Visiblox.Charts.LineSeriesRenderPoint})
member.summary: Iterate over the list of render points and create a new list which includes any 'step' points between the original list of render points.
member.param: The original list of render points.
member.returns: A list of LineSeriesRenderPoint objects that includes the original points along with any step points between them.
